author: {'steamid': '76561198050016554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1499939402}
review:
Impossible de conseiller ou pas ce jeu, l'unique question étant de savoir si vous allez accrocher à l'histoire.

Pourquoi ? Parce qu'il n'y a presque rien d'autre dans ce jeu. 

L'aspect aventure pointer/cliquer est minimaliste. Les premiers chapitres sont si incroyablement courts et contiennent si peu d'objets/actions possibles que vous pouvez oublier votre cerveau au vestiaire. Le troisième est un peu plus long mais passe en mode assisté. Quand ce n'est pas une porte qui s'ouvre pile poil sous votre nez c'est carrément le perso qui nous dit ce qu'il faut lui faire faire. Bien que directive et sans difficulté, l'interactivité est tout de même suffisante pour que le jeu ne se réduise pas à la sensation de juste faire défiler des dialogues.

Donc oui, reste l'histoire et perso j'ai bien eu envie de savoir ce qui liaient ces gens et pourquoi ils étaient là. Mais c'est tellement subjectif. Que dire sans en dévoiler trop ? On est dans du fantastico-onirique noir et mystèrieux mêlant sentiments et psychopathie qui nous présente les élémnets éclatés d'une situation glauque que l'on ne saisira pleinement (façon de parler pour du fantastique toujours un peu obscur et illogique par nature) qu'à la fin. Fin qui se termine en eau de boudin en laissant augurer d'une suite dont je doute qu'elle existe.

Avis positif à prendre avec des pincettes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996550048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1466331367}
review:
The Charnel House Trilogy is an updated re-release of a freeware adventure game, "Sepulchre", which adds two additional chapters, "Inhale" and "Exhale", before and after the original game. Unfortunately, the quality of the new content is mixed at best, and the additional exposition ends up dragging down Sepulchre's strengths as well.

I'm going to start off by stating that, throughout all three parts of the Trilogy, the gameplay is minimal at best. There do not appear to be any situations where you can lose the game, the next objective is always clearly pointed out, and puzzles are simply solved by using the obvious item when necessary. There are some achievements that are technically missable, but I personally got them all on my first playthrough just by examining everything and paying attention. I don't mind this kind of linearity all that much, but the act of going through the environments isn't particularly engaging because the bulk of the game is set in rather drab interiors that aren't affected by the game's proceedings at all — there are zero reasons to backtrack and see if anything has changed, because nothing does unless the plot demands it.

As for the story, if I were to judge by Sepulchre alone, I would say it's just alright. The characters aren't all that interesting, and you will definitely be left confused and unsatisfied by the ending, but taking it as a vignette, it at least has a nice atmosphere that keeps you wondering what will happen next.

On the other hand, Inhale and Exhale are pretty bad. Both of them star a different protagonist and she is only tolerable at best. Inhale is a prologue where you help her get ready for a trip out of her apartment, presumably designed to let players get acquainted with her personality, but frankly this entire portion of the game is incredibly obnoxious and it would have been better to just cut it out entirely. Get this: At one point, you're able to go to her computer, on which is Totally Not A Pixelated Image Of Destructoid, and she starts talking to herself about how the latest review or whatever was controversial. I have no idea if this moment is supposed to convey "yeah I'm cool and enjoy video games like you" or "yeah my life is sad enough that I actively talk about how these things are amusing to nobody," but regardless it's just a really cringey shoutout. Speaking of Destructoid, a character voiced by Jim Sterling is also introduced in this chapter, though I somehow did not notice it was him at this point. Everything else about this chapter is forgettable.

Exhale starts immediately after the events of Sepulchre. Its narrative somewhat clears up the mysteries of the previous chapter, but unfortunately the explanations are uninspired as hell [spoiler](haha, pun)[/spoiler] and there's also an equally uninspiring villain thrown into the mix. Jim Sterling's character shows up again and this time I did notice it was him, right as his dialogue went off a fucking cliff. Seriously, the lines he had to read were so substandard that when he had to put emotion into it I could clearly notice it was him; I had to wonder if he took the role to take the piss out of everything, but judging by what he's said about his work on this game he seems to have sincerely thought it was good (it's not).

Perhaps most insultingly, the Trilogy — which again, is a re-release made, in theory, to fill the plot holes of Sepulchre — has the gall to end on another perplexing cliffhanger, one that promises something far more interesting than these developers could probably ever pull off. As of this writing, whatever sequel was planned has yet to be conceived, and until the unlikely event that it surfaces and miraculously causes the events of its predecessor to be satisfactory in retrospect, I highly recommend just avoiding The Charnel House Trilogy entirely.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990725997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1499806681}
review:
About 2 hours if you don't rush through all the dialog. Hardly call this a game. It is more of an interactive story with some minimal point and click mechanics. There are no difficult puzzles or anything really. Very casual. The story for what is worth, is pretty decent. Decently written dialog and script. Some good voice acting (some bad but not frequent). This definitely leaves the story open and I would def continue playing it.

This is more of an introduction to a story in three small parts (third being longest). Some reviews said it was confusing. I think it set up a decent story with easy to understand tones and elements. It does not give anything away, hence why it may seem confusing, but it is not meant to be totally understood, just some basic ground elements for the rest of the story. 

If we ever get the rest. 

Worth the play if the rest of the story comes out, but not worth the dime alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198192059846', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1499863873}
review:
In short - GOOD! Atmospheric, dream-like mysterious, intriguing story with tasty pixelart.

  NOT for those expecting lots of PUZZLES, CHALLENGE, CHOICES. Also, 'Trilogy' refers to three chapters in the game, not three games or something, sweeties.
_____
Thus, to elaborate a lil':

  Brilliant! That I can say for sure. I saw many people commenting on the shortness of the game, how it gets worse the further it goes and turns from intriguing to meh, something about not so good, even cringy voice acting - and POOP is what I exclaim dramatically in response to this! POOP!
 
 The game is short, yes - there are three chapters, I went through them in less than three hours in one run. Comparing it to longer games of this sort, like Kathy Rain, however... Yes, there is something peculiar here. Kathy Rain, an ok game which just does not go into the directions I would expect it to and stuff, has way more locations, characters to interact with, things to do - and yet it felt SHORTER to me than The Charnel House did. Charnel House first but softly licked, then just sucked me in with its atmosphere, how it greeew as I played! I was sceptical at the beginning, at the end I was in AWE and desiring to see a continuation. It is short, but well put together; tells compelling story, builds its characters, is ambiguos in a delightful sort of way. 

 Puzzles? Meh. Not challenging - you just fly through them to flow further with the story. It may resemble some Visual Novels in this way - clicky click the thingie to get to the next scene, and truly, the clicky part is not there to slap you with a glove, it is a flashing arrow, the "next" button, to clumsily generalize, just more interactive, more compelling.

 So, NO tricky, challenging puzzles here. I dare to think a lot of complaining people got the game expecting them and they got hit by the dissapointment beam pretty hard.

 I find voice acting raging from ok to quite good, getting better as you proceed. And the writing, it made me feel so immersed! At the end, I really was CAPTIVATED and wanted MORE. But I did not feel emptish or like something could be done way better, I did not feel dissapointed - the game surely must have some flaws, though I did not notice them much, focused on them. I went through a story that just grabbed my squishy heart. 
 What I can tell you is that maybe sooome sprites look kind of rectangly (mr Lang), and that while you can either interact with or examine an object, using these two options sometimes leads to the very same results.

 A good, solid tale of suspense; vague, maybe even surreal, yes, dream like at times. It felt GOOD to finish it, see? I felt I completed something; and I was satisfied, and felt this thing special, enriching.

 Want a PECULIAR, SUSPENSEFUL and MYSTERIOUS tale? Yup, grab it! 

 Want a CHALLENGING ADVENTURE with tons of PUZZLE-SOLVING, FINDING SOLUTIONS, ANSWER GETTING..? Nope, this is not it, dearie. See, check Kathy Rain I mentioned before. Maybe, check Fran Bow, too. Both filled with guessing, getting somewhere, combining stuff and problem-solving, longer games... Look at them, really, and realize The Charnel House is simply NOT IT. 

 It is sweet, unsettling, lovely and mmm, so ambiguous, dream-like treat! And it is neat to hear Jimmie boy there, too.  My, Sterling has a beautiful voice. 

 Waiting for continuation or more games in this style!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049461195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1499477134}
review:
well...that was..something. 
I'm not really sure what that was tbh. It's a simple enough game, no real puzzles, but the "story" is really just...a random mishmash of weird stuff that doesn't make much sense. I don't know if something was lost in translation, or we're just supposed to be like "ooo, spooky" but it really was just some random nonsense.
Not to mention this "trilogy" is really just one game split into 3 very short bits. when I finished the first part, I said "is that it?" aloud. 
Overall, I don't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094088790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1498899582}
review:
- A decent adventure game held back by not enough bang for your buck.

Don't be fooled by the "trilogy" in the title: all this is are two 20-minutes introductory acts and one slightly longer third act. One might think this is is just pretentiousness, but the store page boasts that this is "three games in one" which is quite simply misleading: there are free flash games that offer far more content than the first two chapters of this "trilogy".

Charnel House is a one and a half hour-long game with well-drawn AGS graphics but bland writing, generally poor voice acting, a sequel-bait plot that doesn't resolve itself in any satisfactory manner, an overly linear structure and simplistic inventory puzzles that offer no challenge whatsoever. Alex is a relatable enough character, but the rest of the cast comes off as grating, in no small measure due to the "amateur hour" voice work.

The "not recommended" rating refers to the asking price: there are far better (and longer) adventures than this one that are free. As it stands, Charnel House is a passable buy for a dollar during a sale, but the normal $5 price tag will leave you wishing you hadn't, and this combined with the blatant lie in the store page, is what ultimately brings the game down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022311756', 'num_games_owned': 1947, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1498771161}
review:
Игра отличная, особенно интригующей историей  и персонажами. Головоломок тут нет от слова совсем - все понятно интуитивно. Из-за этого проходится очень быстро (у меня она часа 3 свернута была). Но концовка только еще больше все запутывает и неприкрыто намекает на продолжение. Особенно слова после титров, в которых указан год - 2016. Но на дворе середина 2017, а продолжения все нет? В интернете нашел только краткую заметку, где вроде подтвердили скорый выход сиквела. Лето 2017, сиквела нет. Обидно. Хочется наконец побывать в Augur's Peak, раскрыть его тайны и узнать, чем всё закончится. 

Еще из плюсов отмечу саундтрек и озвучку (озвучка 50/50, где-то отлично (Alex), где-то, на мой взгляд, не очень (Don, - особенно вкупе с субтитрами, у Дона текст на экране и то, что говорит актер не совпадают очень часто). Ну и судя по титрам в разработке принимали самое активное участие русские ребята :)

Еще раз: хочу продолжение. 
А так - однозначно рекомендую.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976498153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1606578960}
review:
*Pollice giallo*

Strana avventura che potremmo far rientrare nella categoria dell'horror psicologico. L'impostazione é quella classica punta e clicca, discreti i fondali, ottimo il doppiaggio, la storia è molto interessante ma particolarmente intricata, il finale è aperto a un seguito. Cosa non va: gli enigmi sono praticamente inesistenti, più che parlare con quello e quell'altro non c'è quasi altro da fare, la durata è molto breve, 5-6 ore prendendosela comoda. La cosa più interessante del gioco è che lo si trova al prezzo di una birra, e per quello che offre direi che non è un brutto investimento, detto questo probabilmente per la maggior parte dell'utenza spenderli in una birra forse è la mossa più saggia.

P.S: questo è il gioco dove la parola "fuck" e derivati viene ripetuta più spesso, vedete voi se è un pregio o un difetto.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067038019', 'num_games_owned': 1218, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1496768916}
review:
[b]«Вначале смерть я стану отрицать,
Я буду гневаться и торговаться,
В большой депрессии валяться,
А после смерть смогу принять»[/b]

[u][i]© Александр Сидман[/i][/u]

[h1]«Земля с червями»[/h1]

В вагонах меркнет свет,
Это пoезд играет со мной.
Он вроде есть, а вроде и нет,
Везя меня под землёй.

Бежать отсюда срочно нужно,
Но со своими заперт я грехами.
Я задыхаюсь, как же душно!
А за окном земля с червями.

Проводнику усатому не верь,
Он совсем не тот, кем кажется.
И не ходи в приоткрытую дверь,
Ведь прошлое тут же покажется.

От прошлого не скрыться никуда.
В один конец купил себе билет.
Похоже, что здесь я навсегда,
Ведь из пoезда выхода нет.

Я сделал выдох, после - вдох,
Но боль в висок мне била.
Не дышит тот, давно кто сдох,
А пoезд тот - моя могила!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003233400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1495839320}
review:
The foundation for a great game and story are here. But, in the end, it feels like something that would be sent to a publisher as a *proposal* for a game, not an actual finished product.

These are the reasons I don't recommend this game:
1. For the price, and the genre, the game is unbelievably short.
2. Despite having two "puzzle designers" in the credits, there are no actual puzzles or mysteries to solve.
3. The game ends at what is essentially the end of Act 1.
4. The game ends with a plug for a sequel that seems incredibly unlikely to happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030516476', 'num_games_owned': 5534, 'num_reviews': 465, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1495455583}
review:
"The charnel house trilogy" est une aventure noire et glauque à mi chemin entre le point and clic et la fiction interactive.

Elle se décline en trois chapitres épisodiques de courte durée qui vous entraineront facilement, durant environ 3 heures, dans un univers étrange et horrifique.
Son ambiance et sa narration pourraient vous évoquer quelques similitudes avec les romans de Lovecraft.
Par contre la fin vous laissera en suspend avec de multiples questionnements.

Bien que très courte, on se laissera agréablement happer par cette aventure subtile et intrigante.
A noter que celle-ci n'a pas été traduite en Français, mais elle reste tout à fait compréhensible à celles et ceux ayant encore en tête quelques lointaines notions d'Anglais.

Je n'entrerais pas dans les détails concernant le déroulement de l'intrigue afin de ne pas vous spoiler, je vous invite plutôt à vous lancer dans l'aventure si vous aimez les bons romans et les histoires interactives.

review: This is a short point-and-click 2D game, that is really more of a virtual novel I'd say. The "puzzles" are very simple, and really there to just progress the story. author: {'steamid': '76561198158739744', 'num_games_owned': 698, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1475561173}
review:
三个"独立"的短篇组成的游戏，但实际上故事是连续的，第一篇相当于一个序章，展现了女主出发前的一会时间。第二篇展现了和女主偶遇的男子对于理想主线情节基本上毫无帮助的古怪经历，直到第三篇，剧情才稍稍完整了起来，然后……

我原本以为这是一个神秘系题材的灵异故事的。

结果这其实是一个变态虐待狂一手促成的血腥事件诱发迷之缘由的灵异故事。

据作者称续作会解释这些灵异，对此我只想说，“三部曲”都标上也讲不清楚一个故事的，作为付费游戏也是不容易……

author: {'steamid': '76561198134701607', 'num_games_owned': 975, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1491792846}
review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
This game is strange... [i] very strange [/i]. That is a [b]good[/b] thing though.	

[h1]Style[/h1]
It has a very retro 80s point and click style to it that lend itself overall to the atmosphere. The voice acting pretty good and fits the story nicely. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Mechanically its a standard point and click adventure. My only issue with the game design is that the without a quest tracker or something like that some times I felt [i]slighly[/i] lost on what to do. The puzzles are minimal to the point that they borderline on nonexistent.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Story wise it is super compelling. At first the game feels slow [strike]almost boring[/strike] till the information being given sinks in and you realize how intense things really are. This game is creepy at some points and weird at others but it never feels out of place or cheap. It adds to the overall atmosphere of the game. The game is rather short though; Its about a hour and a half long game.

[u][h1]Overall:[/h1][/u]
Its a good weird game and with its price point shouldnt be passed up.

[i]Edit:
 I do have a [i]small[/i] admission though. I accidentally started with the third Chapter then did the first Chapter and finished with the second Chapter after realizing my mistake. Honsetly after doing all three I like the that format better then doing the Chapters in order.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198272176845', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1491614788}
review:
At first I only bought this game because it was recommended to me after finishing The Last Door series. I asked for similar games and someone was very adamant that I'd like this one. I decided to buy it cause it looked like a descent game for the price, it then just sat in my library for about half a year. Then one day I had no school and said,"What the hell!" and loaded it up... Overall, it had kind of a slow start, but as the story progresses it gets better. The writing is poor and the story is in general, nothing special... I feel like this game is trying to be something more serious than it is... In the end, it's by no means a bad game, but is also by no means a good one... 
If you have a couple hours to kill and enjoy a descent game that may make you think a bit, then feel free to give it a try! For the price, this is a pretty good game.

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197982180153', 'num_games_owned': 2960, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1489802004}
review:
Questo gioco è una menzogna.
Prima di tutto non è una avventura, ma un racconto interattivo mascherato da avventura, e poi non ci sono 3 episodi, ma 3 parti dello stesso racconto, che non ha nemmeno un finale definitivo (in effetti doveva uscirne un seguito nel 2016, ma chissà se mai arriverà).

Trovo questo modo di dividere giochi già brevi in più parti per far credere di acquistare un pacchetto di valore una tattica di vendita sleale, un po come accade con The Last Door, dove almeno le parti sono divise in maniera più netta e ben fatta, ma anche di non avvertire che la storia non termina ma prosegue, forse, in un futuro episodio promesso da uno sviluppatore indie sconosciuto e che quindi non si sa se e quando avverrà.

A dirla tutta, c'è poi la fregatura dell'aspetto del gioco, che fa credere che la produzione sia di un certo livello: la grafica è bella (se vi piace lo stile a bassa risoluzione), la musica è molto bella ed il doppiaggio è di buona fattura (ma non eccelso, ma più probabilmente per i testi che questi poveretti hanno dovuto leggere) ...ma poi arriva la storia, e tutto scade in un film horror di serie b.

La storia scialba ed insensata ed il fatto che una vera e propria avventura grafica non ci sia, sono i problemi che mi hanno fatto odiare questo gioco a tal punto da non vedere l'ora che finisse, e per un gioco che dura solo 2 ore è tutto dire...

Se vi piacciono i film horror tutti uguali che si vedono oggi (bé, negli ultimi 10/15 anni circa) magari potrebbe piacervi, ma per uno come me a cui piacciono i libri di autori classici, questa è solo spazzatura già vista, ed è proprio questo il problema, secondo me.
L'autore punta TUTTO sulla storia, tanto che nel forum del gioco ha creato una discussione che incita i giocatori a teorizzare su quale sia la verità che si cela dietro alla trama, ed i segreti che verranno svelati nel (nei?) prossimo episodio, promuovendo anche dei suoi racconti che ha pubblicato da qualche parte (non ho cliccato).
Mi fanno un po pena (nah) quei tizi che ci provano, e l'autore che con occhiolini, faccine e parole qua è là, tenta di buttare benzina sul fuoco della loro curiosità, quando in realtà non c'è niente da capire visto che è una storia inventata con regole che solo lo scrittore conosce, e ci si affida alla sua buona (o pessima, come in questo caso) scrittura per fare in modo che il suo racconto non abbia paradossi o inesattezze, che potrà comunque risolvere in futuro visto che un mondo fantastico creato da un qualsiasi autore non ha le regole del nostro, e può mutare al suo comando.
E' proprio per questo motivo che quando si leggono libri fantasy o comunque di fantasia (come gli horror), non ha senso cercare di capire, ma bisogna semplicemente seguire il filo e vedere come va a finire.

A me piacciono i racconti di fantasia, ma quando hanno un senso e quando terminano, ma soprattutto quando sono scritti bene. Bé, questo ha tutti i difetti che può avere un racconto del genere: banalità di ogni tipo, "jumpscares" (ma funzionano ancora?), fantasmi che appaiono e scompaiono all'improvviso, la luce che se ne va e guarda un pò, quando si riaccende la stanza è diversa, una bambina, una protagonista goth che dice le parolacce (ma almeno si lava), l'uomo deforme, l'alcolizzato perchè chissà quale oscuro segreto porta con sé...ok ce ne sono altri ma sono stufo di scrivere.

Insomma non è un gioco e la storia è brutta, ma dura solo 2 ore quindi...bé è proprio come guardare uno di quei brutti horror moderni.
Se vi piace il genere...

author: {'steamid': '76561198067396439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1488556138}
review: Captivating plot and a nicely fluent gameplay even for casual adventure gamers such as me. You won't get stuck much, which is a big plus for me as I get easily put off by similar games when I have to pixel hunt, erraticaly combine all items in the inventory or alt+tab to a walkthrough every ten minutes. I can on the other hand imagine that the low puzzle difficulty might be ff-puting for hardcore adventurers. Although I guess this game might be more accurately labeled as a visual novel, and in terms of delivering good storyline and keeping you interested it gets the job done. The only major flaw would be - as mentioned in the other comments - its shortness. Don't get mistaken by my played hours - accidentally left it running on the background for a bit - the whole thing can be finished I think in about 1.5 - 2 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044253018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1487360113}
review:
I would have been very happy to recommend this game if is not so short. My actual time through was about 2.5 hours, but I spent an extra hour trying to find some imaginery secret switch that could reveal contents after the third chapter. 
And then there were none. 

But honetstly, the third chapter was apparently ended without finishing the story! This is outrageous! I paid the money to play a FULL story!!!

Alright, it is not fair if I say the beginning was not attactive, or the writer lack talent. Puzzles are okay in spite of their utter simpleness. I think if the game makers would add 3 or 4 chapters and render the whole story complete, it will worth a recommendation.

But sadly, it seems they have no intention of doing so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043569037', 'num_games_owned': 740, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1463967042}
review:
This was a difficult choice for me. While I definitely enjoyed parts of this game and overall felt it an enjoyab;e experience, there are too many things holding it back for me to really recommend it. First of all, it's length; I genuinely thought the game had bugged out or something after the first chapter because it was so short, like it didn't feel complete, so I was left unsatisfied and, while the other two chapters were better in that regards, I still feel like the whole game could have done with being a bit longer. The chapters are also somehwat disjointed, which isn't exactly a problem, but with already feeling too short, I feel it just doesn't work out.
My biggest disappointment however was with the ending, I won't go into details but it seemed way too over the top. I greatly appreciated the subtley of the creep factor this game had, in fact it was one of my faorite parts of it, so the ending not only seemed overdramatic to the point of ridiculousness (I was actually laughing during it), it seems wholly out of place and really drags the rest of the game down with it for me.
I would have likely recommended this game if it stayed consistent in its disturbance factor, instead of going for the shock WHAM! ending, even if the game was frustratingly short.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088213112', 'num_games_owned': 1213, 'num_reviews': 257, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1487281388}
review:
Pro:
- No real lengths
- Not overexplaining things
- Good narrative and dramaturgy
Neutral: 
- It's not a Point&Click triology, it's just a 2h visual novel. I for myself was fine with that, I enjoy short and sweet stories and don't care much about gameplay.
Con: 
- The second part is only very loosly connected to the rest of the game and more or less an atmospheric advertisement for a game yet to come (and to by), not more. I feel a bit scammed here.
- The final confrontaton was a bit over the top for my taste. They should have presented the revelations [spoiler]from Rob[/spoiler] at a slower pace, maybe make the protagonist figure out more things by herself, step by step. Even if everything is a metaphor for something else, it was too much ad-hoc content and cruelty at this point.

Recommended since I enjoyed the 2 hours all in all. And there lots of interesting theories and thoughts about what really has happend, if you love to dive into speculations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071545213', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1485467660}
review:
После прохождения  Richard and Alice я естественно захотел посмотреть, что  же я там ещё купил от этой студии. Самое то для тихой ночи - спустится в склеп. 

Плюсы: Атмосфера, сюжет, стилистика, некоторая схожесть с тем же the Cat Lady, весьма хороший OST - особенно в баре. 

Минусы: Историю слишком вываливают, и не те части, которые бы хотелось. Психопата можно было показать интереснее. Линии диалогов порой неправильно построены (спрашиваешь то, что уже знаешь). 

Вердикт: Да, я рекомендую это игру для тех, кому нравятся мрачные адвенчуры с психотропным хоррором. Но Richard and Alice у этой студии было крепче.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988004463', 'num_games_owned': 1327, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1484811323}
review:
It's 2 hours long and completely linear with very few puzzles. It's important to highlight that this isn't an "adventure game" - it's interactive fiction. You don't explore, you just point the character to their next objective, which is always something obvious. 

The value of the game depends entirely on whether you appreciate the story, the voice acting, the art and the music. Did I enjoy them? Not really. There were good bits (the main character's voice acting & back story), adequate bits (art and music), but the story and the other characters were disappointingly flat and underdeveloped.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993118789', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1484606654}
review:
The ground beneath me calls my name...

A decent attempt at creating a classic gothic horror tale mixed with a dash of strong-willed and unusual characters that populate it, make The Charnel House Trilogy a fun, thoughtful and chilling ride.

I'll avoid the plot of the game entirely since the player's enjoyment comes from knowing little to none on what awaits her/him. The Charnel House trilogy is made up of three short episodes, and you can look at around two hours to finish them all. Story and the motives the game deals with are interesting and unnerving as they should be, and have left a lasting impression on me. Some of the morbid history subject Charnel House deals with have made me pause the game once in a while to check on the net if it really was the case (and to my morbid curiosity and excitement, they were :).Since the game was made with AGS engine, it is bound to low resolution but detailed 2D art coupled with great music and sound effects make up for it. Voice acting on the other hand is a mixed bag with some performances being very good to other sounding amateurish, and can on a few occasions pull you out of the game's atmosphere and experience. Also the first two episodes are way too short, leaving the atmosphere of the horror not nearly enough time to bloom and leave a terrifying mark on me, but the third somewhat lengthier and meatier episode successfully produces the sense of trepidation, uneasiness and wonderment, and makes up for the short and trimmed first two episodes. Just be warned that the ride ends with a cliffhanger, and the sequel the developers have announced is already behind the schedule. -.-

So if you are looking for something spooky, in a vein of Gabriel Knight or Phantasmagoria, made on an indie budget and that lasts a fraction of above-mentioned adventure classics, I moderately recommend you try out this little gem. It won't rock your world in fear, but it will provide a few cold dashes of dread for an evening :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198106457925', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1483285090}
review:
I spent the last few hours wondering wether to give a positive or negative review and well, you can see by yourselves to what conclusion I came.
I'm a little bummed by the fact that it's more an interractive story than a real game and it's very short (2 hours and you're done) but that story guys, THAT STORY: WOAH!
I'm gonna be honest I thought it was inspired by a book and my first thought was "Wait I gotta pause this and google who the author is then I'm gonna buy the novel. Period". Props to the mind who gave birth to the story.
I'm not gonna complain because the game hasn't been translated in my native language as someone did: there's everything you need to know about the game on its Steam page so you know what you're buying. You don't know english? Your fault, I don't see why the creators should suffer for your ignorance. You want it translated? Ask for it. Wait for it. 
Nice music, really enjoyed the voiceover.
The game is really easy, you can't go wrong.
Only thing is: it's not worth the price. It's a great story but it's too short and leaves you questioning some stuff (that, as I read, should probably get cleared in the next longer game) so buy it when on sale because for the full price you could buy hours of good reading.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055778112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1481919019}
review:
Für den Adventurefan interessantes Futter für einige unterhaltsame Stunden. 

Man spielt zwei unterschiedliche Personen, die beide auf dem Weg zu einer Insel sind und steigen in einem seltsamen Zug ein, der sehr spät fährt. In diesem spielt sich das ganze Spiel ab. 

In Bezug auf die Ereignisse im Spiel kann man leider nur wenig darauf eingehen, aber wenn einem nach einer Weile flau im Magen wird, zeigt das Spiel gut Wirkung.

Ein zweites Durchspielen ist empfehlenswert, da man dann die Ereignisse am Anfang gleich in einem anderen Licht sieht.

review: This short point and click horror game is immensely effective in what it set out to do. author: {'steamid': '76561198006321953', 'num_games_owned': 603, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1482573179}
review:
I enjoy short & serious stories, even when they're linear with easy puzzles, like this.

I went into it not knowing what to expect, and Part I felt very "Blackwell Epiphany", especially as it has the same artist, and features exploration of the bookish female protagonist's apartment.

But in Part II, the vibe is much more "The Last Door". There's deep supernatural mystery, and increasingly offputting occurances soon take you into "what the fuck" territory. I thought the music, writing and pace made for great atmopshere here.

I felt Part III lost the wind out of its sails to an extent, as it was much longer than the other parts, the plot becomes unnecessarily convoluted, and the mystery falls away too early to become more of a traditional horror, in which the protogonist behaves nonchalantly towards the supernatural nature of her situation, focusing only on the interpersonal drama. Some of the (otherwise very good) voice acting also misses its note on a few lines in this section (or perhaps I was just taken out of the story enough to notice it here). Still, there are some good reveals and moments in Part III and overall I enjoyed it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194121493', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1481141419}
review:
The Charnel House Trilogy - игра достойная Вашего внимания. Постараюсь объяснить почему. Мне не очень просто было написать обзор в моём обычном стиле, аля плюсы-минусы. Очень уж трудно в данном случае это сделать. 
      Графика - на любителя. Я фанат графики, так что мне потребовалось немного времени, чтобы привыкнуть. Как только привыкаешь к графике, второе, это как правило то, что приходит на слух. И тут есть два момента. 
      Музыка - классная, мне понравилась. Озвучка персонажей, вот, не совсем. Где-то не до конца вжились в роль, а где-то слышится некачественный микрофон и хоть это не раздражает, но немного мешает погружению.
      Сюжет - интересный. Затягивает. Заставляет задуматься. Довольно открытый, и почитав комменты разработчика, я понял, что каждый может понимать игру по-своему. Но я реально засел на 2 часа и погрузился по полной. 
      Атмосфера - вышка. Если интересен стиль, я бы сказал, что это больше триллер, чем хоррор. Страшно тут не из-за зомби и не из-за привидений, игра давит психологически. Есть какое-то чувство тревоги и периодически в голову лезут втфэшки :D
      В целом, игра мне понравилась и приятно было услышать, что игру ждёт сиквел под названием Augur Peak. Рекомендую к приобретению на распродаже, так как 5.49 евро мне было-таки жалко за такую игрушку, за то на блэкфрайдей, когда её цена упала до еврика с копейками было очень даже найс :)

review:
Pros:
 - Good story. Creepy without being over the top.
 - Full voice acting.
 - Nice Soundtrack

Cons:
 - Short. Only a few hours long at most.
 - Story lacks a conclusive ending.
 - Voice acting can be a bit off at some points.
 - Very linear. No real choice and always pretty clear what you should be doing.

Conclusion: 
A nice, be it short, interactive novel good for an evening of phsycological/supernatural fun. The voice acting is for the most part good and combined with a really nice atmospheric soundtrack kept me pretty immersed in the game from begining to end. The only really bad thing I can say about it is it lacks a proper ending which kind of makes it feel like there was supposed to be a part two that never came.

review:
An atmospheric little adventure game that seems like it's more the prequel to another series or a larger game. There's a decent amount of intrigue that doesn't get explained, but as it seems more to be to setup something larger I'm okay with that.

The characters are fairly well realized given how short the game is, about 80-90 minutes or thereabout, and the voice acting is pretty good (aside from a few minor side characters who sound like they were recorded over skype). The music is pretty lowkey and moody which sets the tone well, and it's done by Jack de Quit if you're familiar with the Friends at the Table podcast and know some of his stuff from there.

I hate getting into the cost versus time played value proposiution argument, but just be aware that this is a pretty short game, so if that's an issue maybe wait to pick it up on sale. Having now played it though, I'd probably be okay with picking it up at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007688772', 'num_games_owned': 1263, 'num_reviews': 649, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1479851463}
review:
Hra, které je docela jiná, než jak působí ze Steamové prezentace.
Za prvé, název. The Charnel House Trilogy. Očekával jsem plnohodnotnou trilogii her, která mi vystačí na mnoho hodin. Dostal jsem tři kratičké kapitoly, které se bez problému dají dohrát za dvě hodiny. Herních obrazovek je sotva deset a i tak se některé jen opakují s pár obměnami.
Za druhé, žánr. Vypadá to jako klasická adventura, čemuž hodně napomáhá i herní engine používaný jinými adventurami (Gemini Rue, Technobabylon, pentalogie Blackwell a další). Je to ale pravda jen z části. Interakce i používání předmětů je velmi limitované a hádanky triviální. Děj je zcela lineární a posunuje se kupředu skoro samovolně, bez většího hráčova přičinění. Obvykle stačí splnit očekávanou akci a hra sama aktivuje jinou událost a naznačí, co dál. Spíš jde o interaktivní příběh než o tradiční adventuru.
Za třetí, příběh. Hra už podle názvu působí jako uzavřené dílo, ale opak je pravdou. Z hromady nastolených záhad a podivností se nevysvětlí prakticky nic, konec už otevřenější být nemůže. Jde tak spíš o počátek nějaké delší série než o samostané dílo.

Zatím jen kritizuji, ale přesto hodnotím pozitivně. Pokud totiž přijmete výše zmíněné vlastnosti, dostanete slušnou hru se snovou až lovecraftovskou atmosférou. Děj, byť neuzavřený, má svoje momenty a minimálně jedno odhalení je poměrně šokující. Na vysoké úrovni je i dabing většiny postav, především hlavní představitelky. A zcela úchvatná je pixelartová grafika a plynulé ruční animace. Tak kvalitní, detailně zpracovaný pixelart jsem dlouho neviděl.
Takže doporučit můžu, ale musíte vědět, do čeho jdete.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101031094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1479069071}
review:
This game is awesome, THIS is how real psychological horror looks like in my humble opinion. It doesn't contain a lot of jump-scares or gore, but it is still one of the most distrubing games I've ever played. 

I think a big part of why this game is so deeply terrifying without any cheap tricks is that the stories are about just regular people, like those who you can live next door to. I've finished it in ~3.3 hours, but the game still took time to establish characters enough that I felt connected to them on good enough level to really care.

The atmosphere is awesome, soundtrack is really nice too and the voice acting is done very tastefully and with care.

11/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198031261101', 'num_games_owned': 2321, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1511376822}
review:
PnC/Adventure-game nut that I am, there's still only a small handful of the games that raise my expectations to notable heights. This was one of the handful, and it didn't disappoint.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Okay, to start with: This is short. Expect to complete the entire "trilogy" within 1.5 to 3 hours. (It's better to think of the three "games" as simply being chapters of the same story, of which only the third one has any firm length.)
This is a basic puzzle-adventure PnC: Pick up items, combine items, interact with things. That said, all the puzzles are simple [Tip: Your items are accessible via a tab up top, and at one point in the game you do need to click the scroll button on that tab to get the item you need to progress], so veterans shouldn't expect to find any surprises or hint of a challenge. If you're new to adventure games, this may be a good entry point- the narrative pushes you pretty clearly into the approach you need to take with each puzzle.

Interface has a few minor clunky elements, but the game is for the most part smoothly handled and intuitive. The animation is very well detailed, and matches the charm of the art style quite well.

Most everything is examinable and interactable, often to the very amusing musings of your protagonist. While the game may lack in puzzle depth, it makes up for it with the detail of its interactive fiction and charm of its humor. 

4.25/5

[b]Audio[/b]
While generally speaking the voice acting is above par, there's spotty bits [including one side character in one single scene that sounds like she's speaking from 5 feet away from a microphone], mainly in the voice actors simply not speaking as fluidly as you'd expect. However, none of it is particularly grating, the game has full voice acting, and you can skip forward in dialogue any time you like. So there's no harm if you do find a character particularly annoying or dull to listen to.
Generalities aside, the lead voice actress doesn't suffer any of the flaws I mentioned- she's a delight to listen to, and both the writing and vocalization of her dialogues is quite enjoyable.

The music is similarly delightful, and this is one of the rare games I'll be making sure to get hold of the OST for. It's all ambient mood-setting music that you tune out as you play- but then, that's what it's supposed to be. If you take a moment to listen to it, it's quite richly developed, and ought be appealing to fans of ambient music styles. Typically, I'm the 'mute the background music' type, but I'm glad this game didn't have an option for that.
Flip side, if you do happen to dislike the background music, the single volume slider means you'll have to take voice acting out along with the music.

4.75/5

[b]Plot & Writing[/b]
While the supernatural elements dominant this game, at heart it's a psychological thriller, and those are the parts that'll stick out. The content is all adult, as is the writing, so while the gameplay is entry-level difficulty, it may be a bit too morbid and curse-heavy for younger players.
The plot is solid, between the first and third chapter, telling a twisted short story and using supernatural elements as the catalyst for revealing the pasts of the characters involved. The second chapter, on the other hand, is just a bizzare acid trip that hopefully'll have more import in tying in the game's sequel [Augur Peak] than it did in tying into this game. Still, it's a bit of an interesting experience, and it does set a good platform for the last chapter, so it's not a negative inclusion into the game. Rather, it feels less like filler, and more like an experience that ends up being a bit jarring in comparison to the more coherent style of the other two chapters.

Writing is a bit inconsistant or forced in places, but not to any degree that'll jar you out of the story flow. For the most part, it's quite appealing, and with a modern, straightforward sensibility. The game doesn't hold to tension for long, switching between bizzareness and straightforward exposition quite readily- but that also means the reveals never feel forced, stretched out for so long as to lose their meaning [in other words, it's not like romances in drama TV series].

There's no real conclusion to the game, as the game seems to be intended as a prologue to the sequel, but it does wrap up the specific story it has to tell quite well. In that sense, it's quite a good example of a prologue, mixing telling a self-contained short story with setting things up for something larger.

4.5/5


[b][i]Summary[/i][/b]
A good, bite-sized adventure game for mature gamers, suitable for a quick Point 'n Click fix or an entry-point into PnCs.
Excellent attention to detail, a compelling protagonist, fully voiced dialogue, and strong music carry the game, while weak puzzles, short game length, a disjointed second chapter, and an interface and writing just a touch short on polish limit the game's impact.

I can definitely recommend this game, and am highly looking forward to its sequel. :)

[u]Final Score[/u]: 4.5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561197997506993', 'num_games_owned': 1127, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1478012270}
review:
Do I recommend the game? For the full price, no. Less than a dollar? Yeah, maybe.

The Charnel House Trilogy is more like a visual novel than a traditional point&click puzzle game, because the puzzles are very easy and the game characters are pretty specific about what the protagonist ought to do next. The story had its moments, the pixel art is quite pretty and there's a nice dark atmosphere. I'd say that the horror elements are not there to scare you, but to make you feel creepy and lonely.

What irks me is that the game gives itself too much credit. It only takes an hour or so to complete and there are many references to some bigger story that's apparently out there. At the end there's a blatant sequel hook which made the Charnel House Trilogy seem like a prologue instead of a self-standing game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990639403', 'num_games_owned': 3540, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1477971358}
review:
I enjoyed this short horror adventure. It was especially perfect to play on Halloween night. I won't say much about the story, but it requires you to think a bit. None of the horror is "Boo!" horror, more 'think about it later isn't that effed up' horror. Puzzles aren't overly complicated and I only got a little confused once. Never required me to look anything up. There are some missable achievements you may want to look up if you don't feel like playing through twice, though.

80 minutes and it was on sale for $1.50 which is pretty much perfect. Recommended at that price for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033995360', 'num_games_owned': 2161, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1477871055}
review: Malgré quelques effets trop grossiers pour être efficaces, The Charnel House Trilogy est un point & click d'une noirceur à la subtilité rare. C'est une courte lecture, une grosse nouvelle, un frisson, un trait d'horreur qui nous parcourt l'épine dorsale sans jamais nous faire vraiment peur. Juste une menace qui rôde, trace des cercles assez loin autour de notre fauteuil pour ne jamais nous brusquer, un danger qui ne fait que chuchoter, une petite mort qui se murmure. Bien écrit et superbe à l'oeil, The Charnel House Trilogy est une mini-frayeur, un ticket de train fantôme qui ne fera crier ni les grands peureux ni leurs grandes peureuses, une tache d'ombre à laquelle il sera bon de sacrifier une nuit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118131858', 'num_games_owned': 874, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1476989560}
review:
The Charnel House Trilogy is a small point & click with 3 chapters: Inhale, Exhale and Sepulchre.
We follow alternately Alex and Dr. Lang in a somewhat unusual story, full of mysteries, twists and darkness. I will say no more, I don’t want to spoil.

I was certainly very surprised, I did not expect to be so absorbed in the story. During the two hours of gameplay, many questions gnaw at us, small pieces of the "puzzle" appear here and there before finally discovering the more or less surprising outcome depending on what we’ve already understood of the story.

The Charnel House Trilogy can be called horror game by its oppressive atmosphere and well-crafted script.
I can only recommend it to fans of the genre and those who are just curious.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/29451654/]My Curator Page[/url]

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The Charnel House Trilogy est un petit point & click constitué de 3 chapitres :  Inhale, Sepulchre et Exhale.
Nous suivons tour à tour Alex et le docteur Lang dans une histoire quelque peu atypique, pleine de mystères, de rebondissements et de noirceur. Je n’en dirai pas plus, au risque de spoiler.

J’ai été sans aucun doute très surprise, je ne m’attendais pas à être autant absorbée par l’histoire. Durant les deux heures que dure ce jeu, de nombreuses questions ne cessent de nous tarauder, des petits morceaux du « puzzle » apparaissent par ci par là pour finalement arriver au dénouement plus ou moins surprenant suivant ce qu’on avait déjà compris.

The Charnel House Trilogy peut être qualifié de jeu d’horreur de par son atmosphère oppressante et son scénario bien ficelé. 
Je ne peux que le recommander aux amateurs du genre et aux curieux.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132824678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1472628330}
review:
I love adventure games, so I was really ready to get into this game and play it for a few days straight, so I was kind've shocked when it took me no time at all. Not that a short adventure game is some kind of affornt to nature, but the story itself starts and abruptly stops, making you feel like... where's the rest? But it's mostly my fault for not doing enough research/reading, as I later found out that this is technically what the developer called an "extended intro" for their next game coming out soon. Calling it a trilogy is a bit deceptive as it's all-in-all about five hours of gameplay, and is not a complete story, but rather the prologue, which is something one should have in mind when thinking about purchasing it. 

I would reccommend it though because everything about it is really good. The interface is perfectly easy to use, the art is all very beautiful, and it was very easy to get into with lots of things going on that you can spend time wondering the significance of. It's far from boring, and it's obvious that a lot of effort went into the look and feel. Wait for an inevitable package with the whole game if you want, but if you're a big fan of quality adventure games, your money could certainly be used support worse projects. Not gonna lie, the dissappointment makes it hard to give a lavish review, but it is a good start. Some of the plot points seem a bit rushed towards the end, but I'll save judgement for the overarching plot when the whole game is out. Fact of the matter is: it definitely made me want to buy their next game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016476102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1469674105}
review:
A cool, quick, psych-thriller adventure game. I got this game on sale - it's a quick one, so the $6 tag might make some flinch, but I found myself having a lot of fun with it. There's a few points worth making, though. 

Calling this "3 adventure games in one" is a bit of a stretch for what you get. The game has three chapters which all depend on one another for any sort of coherence, and should be played chronologically ideally. The games are straight adventure, with not a lot of real puzzles persay aside from the typical adventure game "rub all inventory items on all things". It's pretty clearly more a story using the game format as a mode of delivery, but I think it works well overall. 

Charnel House Trilogy feels more like a really good prologue than a whole story in and of itself. Everything is very trippy, symbolic, and abstract. Some people, like myself, love that sort of thing. Others don't. A free demo of the second chapter, Sepulchre, is available on Owl Cave's website (and on here) and if you're having doubts, I suggest giving it a go - it will definitely give you enough of the overall tone for you to make a call on. 

You can gather most of what's going on generally speaking by reading between the lines of the game, but even then there's several narrative questions that need answering. The good news is, the devs say the sequel is coming of within 2016 (ideally), so honestly I may wait until that comes out to really give this a go. 

Technically, the game is sound. Owl Cave and Wadjet Eye share several brains, so if you're a fan of Blackwell or any of the others, you'll definitely be getting vibes of that in the art and music. Voice acting is also relatively clear and of pretty good quality - lots of good actors here. Maybe don't fullscreen it, though. It makes otherwise nice sprite art look like lint on your screen. 

Overall, I'd say play the demo and see if you're more enthralled or infuriated. If you like it, purchase it - but maybe wait until the sequel comes out if more solid answers are important to you in a story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023287533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1469291940}
review:
I purchased this game during the Steam sale and wasn't sure what to expect.  

I was delightfully surprised with the story and concept of the game overall.  A standard adventure game, The Charnel House Trilogy, provides moderately easy puzzles, but the story far outshines anything else it has to offer.  During two chapters you play as the young woman, Alex and one chapter you play as Howard Lang aboard the mystery train, Gloria.  Unraveling the mystery of the train is the basis of the story and it's stories like these which are the most enjoyable because the meaning isn't laid out, it's somewhat open to interpretation.

I do hope there is a sequel as I'm dying to dig further into the mystery of Augur Peak.

Gameplay was almost three hours for me, but I'm a pixel clicker.  Normal players would probably be two hours or less so if you're okay with spending six bucks for two hours then knock yourself out or just wait for a sale, but buy this game regardless.  It's worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031651888', 'num_games_owned': 798, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1468873624}
review:
L'intérêt de "the Charnel House Trilogy" repose sur son scénario mystérieux. Ici, point d'énigmes si ce n'est ramasser quelques objets et les utiliser de la manière la plus évidente qui soit ("utiliser clé sur porte"). Nous avons affaire à une "histoire interactive" plus qu'à un véritable point'n click.

Attention, vous finirez le jeu avec un petit nombre de questions restées volontairement sans réponse : votre imagination et esprit de déduction devra faire le reste. Le forum Steam comporte d'ailleurs certaines discussions dévoilant des théories très intéressantes. Si vous êtes du genre à vouloir une réponse à tout, claire et précise, alors passez votre chemin.

Côté durée de vie, c'est faiblard. Pour un jeu qui s'appelle "Trilogy", nous avons en fait trois minuscules chapitres, et vous aurez fini le jeu en 1h30 - 2h grand maximum. A noter qu'une suite est prévue et devrait sortir en 2016.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001597265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1468208063}

author: {'steamid': '76561198022425833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1468049526}
review:
[i]The Charnel House Trilogy[/i] is a point-and-click horror/adventure game that lasts about two and a half hours. Right up until the last five minutes or so, I thought I was following the plot pretty well. Then the Big Reveal finally came, the nature of the game's paranormal threat was explained, and... I still don't get what was "really" supposed to be going on.

Nevertheless, I enjoyed the ride. The story is paced well, with creepy elements being added in just the right amounts and increments to keep the narrative momentum going (and the player feeling increasingly uneasy). The voice acting is also quite good for what appears to be a fairly low-budget game (video game critic Jim Sterling plays a supporting character).

A warning though: this is not a game for puzzle fans. Most of the game unfolds through simple fetch quests ("Hey friend, would you go to the bar and get me a shot of whiskey?") and the resulting dialogue upon completion of said fetching ("Thanks for the whiskey. Hey, did I ever tell you about...."). A few puzzles are interspersed here and there, but the answers are so heavily hinted that I was never stuck for more than thirty seconds or so -- and this is coming from a guy who almost always resorts to a walkthrough at least a few times before finishing most other adventure games. In other words, play [i]The Charnel House Trilogy[/i] for its story and atmosphere rather than for an intellectual challenge.

Oh, and just in case you're confused by the game's title: it's called a "Trilogy" because it's told in three chapters (each lasting about 45 minutes). All three chapters are included when you buy the game, and are all accessed from one main menu. As far as I know, there aren't any other games in the series besides this one (though I believe a sequel is planned).

review:
The game is an atmospheric and stylish point and click adventure. The art style is retro 2D. The story narration is good and game play mechanic is simple. No QTE. Just enjoy the story as you progress. The background is well done. The game is short, it took me 4 hours to comlete but your milage may vary. 

Overall, The Charnel House Triolgy is a good game which delivers an absorbing story along with a unique art style. However, the ending still didn't answer all the questions, so hopefully next chapter will answer them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966594088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1467602340}
review:
First of all, this "trilogy" isn't really a trilogy. It's a set of three chapters that are themselves the first part in a series. Notice how that title says "The Charnel House"? Well, there's no Charnel House in this game. Instead, this is about the travel TO Charnel House - some place that is said to appear in the NEXT game. ...so this whole game is some sort of pointless prequel.

It's a prequel about two protagonists: A generic professor, and a generic teen, and their backstories told through completely random scenes that defy all logic, up to the point where the randomness is just made fun of.

...and this isn't the first time that the creators have done this. That last game from them I played was ALSO about a guy and a girl stuck somewhere, just flashing back to backstory. At least The Charnel House was better animated.

Game darts back and forwards between random symbolic horror and boring teen angst of the worst sort, and there's very little payoff along the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990873624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1466785360}
review:
I was so taken aback by this game I had to write a review to vouche for it, because despite the recent mixed reviews I think it has alot going for it and deserves a chance. I never really even nod towards games like this and I honestly didn't expect too much, but for some reason it was really different than the other games out there. I would easily recommend this if you're looking for a more story driven "horror" game that you can formulate theories for during the next several weeks. 

If you're looking to be scared though, it's probably not for you. It's definitely more atmosphere and narrative content which is meant to be appreicated and thought about. It's full of alot of human/existential/"self discovery" themes as opposed to jump scares - which just isn't for everyone. 

It is pretty short which is sort of the downside, took about an hour and a half. 
As well as the dialouge is sometimes pretty cringe-worthy.

But several hours later and I'm still left thinking about it and still wondering what the hell any of it means.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045679303', 'num_games_owned': 561, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1465083343}
review:
Jeu très court et très décevant.

Quelques rares clics très dirigés entre les longs textes des personnages qui racontent leur vie. Il y a des fantômes, on se demande bien pourquoi ? Pour copier les Blackwell ?

De même, il y une fille dans le 1er, un gars dans le 2ème et de nouveau la fille dans le 3ème. Et pourtant, à la fin des 3 "jeux", j'ai eu l'impressoin d'avoir moins agi que dans Blackwell Legacy à lui tout seul.

C'est glauque, il y a même une scène de torture qui est racontée dans Exhale. Scène qui n'apporte rien à l'histoire... heureusement ils n'ont pas représenté le truc en images.

Bref si je pouvais revenir en arrière je ne l'aurais pas joué ; même si on me donnait de l'argent pour ça.

A moins d'être malade (ou masochiste), évitez cette... chose.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977318125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1465830969}
review:
I love a good old-school point 'n' click adventure game, and The Charnel House Trilogy seemed to fit the bill when I purchased it. It's a relatively short experience, taking me around two hours to finish up and earn all the achievements too. What you get here is a fun, interesting little mystery, split into three 'chapters' that vary in length. The first two are pretty brief, and the third is the longest, with most of the plot twists and developments happening there. There's a horror element to the game, but also a bit of humour and some nods and winks to the gaming community.

The voice acting is decent, particularly from the two lead characters - Alex and Harry. Jim Sterling voices a character here too, and he's suitably over-the-top and impassioned. He's clearly having a lot of fun with the role. The weakness in the voice acting is mainly that they were all clearly recorded separately, possibly over Skype, so there's a difference in quality that I found a bit distracting. It's the nature of the game and how it was made, however, and I found it easy to forgive those issues. You work with what you've got to hand.

I think what some people who have left negative reviews are struggling with is the fact that this is more of a narrative experience. Sure, you're pointing and clicking, but the game very much pushes you in the right direction throughout. There are a couple of puzzles, but they're very, very easy and only really serve to push the plot along. It's a pretty captivating plot too, although I felt like most of my questions went unanswered by the time I reached the end. There will almost certainly be a sequel that fleshes out some of what we see here, but I wasn't disappointed by what I saw. There's some real promise here in terms of where the story could go. A bit more gameplay and some clearer answers would be great in the future, but this is a good starting point and a decent little game to boot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028932676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1465174858}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996274436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1465095836}
review:
If being confused by a video game's ambiguous plot frightens you, you're in for scary times from start to finish with this one. Well, okay, from about a third of the way in to finish. Me, I was mostly just annoyed. I mean, I guess they're going for a kind of "Twilight Zone" thing, but it doesn't seem to quite work out. I get that I was supposed  to feel some kind of creeping existential dread, but mostly I was afraid the whole game would be as self-referential as the first chapter. I thought maybe reading the book that keeps popping up throughout the game might help, but as near as I can tell it doesn't actually exist, so I guess that's not an option. At least the poem in the first trailer sort of makes sense now, in a way. Kind of.
Also, writers: If you've got a character who's lived in New York City her whole life, and is apparently voiced by the only American on your cast, maybe let the voice actress go over the script and call your attention to turns of phrase that Americans don't normally use?







Spoiler: The ending will not help you make sense of the rest of it. I was really, really hoping it would.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994117737', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1463247971}
review:
Technically great but poorly designed adventure game

Adventure game by definition is about progressing the story by solving problems and puzzles. 
Charnel house has none, you are basically herded into one train cabin, where you pickup single item and a herded towards next cabin where you use the very same item you've picked up earlier. 
Charnel house plays like an interactive novel where you know exactly how it ends by the time you finish chapter and 2 and just just click away for the next 30-40 minutes to see the very ending you've been expecting all along. 
Game title suggests trilogy, where in fact it's a 3 chapters, each lasting about 20-30 minutes.

It's a real shame, because the game is very nicely drawn and features excellent voiceover.
One may argue the game's low price tag makes up for all its shortcommings, but if you can get games like broken sword 1 or 2 for the same price, charnel house is really just a waste of  time

author: {'steamid': '76561198122163777', 'num_games_owned': 1846, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1463134233}
review:
I can not actually recommend this title for players looking for a deep, point & click, atmospheric game.  It isn't a terrible experience, and I really liked the beginning of the game, but there are some points which seem misleading from the get go.  The store page advertizes this as "Three thrilling, horrifying adventure games in one" and that is just not true.  Not only is this not three adventures, it doesn't even feel like ONE whole and complete adventure.

This title contains three short scenes, which are loosely related and leave an open-ended interpretation of what actually has occured during the course of the story presented.  The first scene is excellently narrated, introduces the main character and piques the player's interest and, although very short, draws the player into the world.  The second scene is a bit surreal, does not exactly correlate to the first scene, but does still allude to it, and brings a bit of a psychological teasing to the narrative.  The third and longest scene is best described as "meh" and kind of diffuses the interest that was piqued in the first and second scenes with a haphazardly thrown out, cliched type of story.  And the very end of the game is an allusion to that fact that another game may come in the future which will bring the player back to learn more of what may or may not have happened in the course of this game.

And "game" is used in the loosest sense of the word here.  There is hardly any game at all.  This is more of a psychological experience where the story is narrated (with some excellent voice acting for the most part) and the player is allowed to click on a few icons for added description while the story unfolds itself.

I actually enjoyed most of this title, but as this is being billed as multiple point&click adventures rolled into one, I think that many people who are going to purchase this title are going to end up with something that they feel disappointed with when they have finished.  Also the rushed and unfinished story that the third scene leaves the player with just doesn't lead to a satisfied feeling upon completion.  I am 100% for a psychologically baffling story that people can have long dialogues about long after they are over, but more of the picture should have been presented at the ending rather than forcing people to purchase a different game at a different time to get the satisfaction that completing a game should give.  And for these reasons, I would not recommend this title to fans of the point & click genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022458781', 'num_games_owned': 2808, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1462573711}
review: Devo sconsigliare questo gioco ai videogiocatori italiani in quanto non è fruibile pienamente senza una conoscenza approfondita della lingua inglese, non essendoci presenti i sottotitoli in italiano. L'adventure, come peraltro comprensibile, ha come aspetto fondamentale la storia, narrata attraverso lo scambio di battute tra i protagonisti: queste ultime sono serrate, senza possibilità di rallentarle per tradurle e comprenderle, tanto più che si usano slang ed espressioni non facili da tradurre. Inoltre la storia, come in altre produzioni di adventure dello stesso tipo, è narrata volutamente in modo enigmatico, e pretende attenzione massima sui particolari narrati. Come da mio standard quando non è presente la traduzione in italiano nei casi necessari, il mio giudizio è negativo, a prescindere dagli altri elementi del gioco

author: {'steamid': '76561198014660882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1499787225}
review:
(Spoiler-free)

A mercifully brief, on-rails (pun) point-'n-click with uneven execution. Since I purchased the game at under $2 USD, I can't really complain much. For the retail price of $6 USD, I'd save your money for a longer, more interesting game. I had really hoped for more game and less grinding narrative. 

Too few real puzzles and a mediocre reveal make this one a don't-buy at full price.

Nevertheless, the score is quite good because it instills deadful foreboding. I think it's easily the best element in the entire game, and if (as the climax hints) they intend on making more in this series, they should continue with their current composition. 

The art, despite being extremely limited in scope, is on par with modern p-n-c's. My estimate of the actual places you can visit includes: one apartment, a train station, and a train interior with between 6-8 largely identical compartments that alter in presentation as you progress. So, in total, there are maybe 2 dozen individually constructed environments. One additonal room pops up for narrative purposes, but it isn't interactive. Plenty of good stories have taken place in a small arena, but this is one tale that would benefit from more depth of milieu. The cramped quarters of Charnel House don't derail the game (pun), but they don't give us much variety, either. The game ends up feeling claustrophobic, though not in a good way.

The voice acting (by a handful of game professionals, no less) is technically proficient, though not particularly impressive. Sterling's addition seems like a mis-cast, perhaps. His voice is off-putting, no doubt, but it doesn't quite fit. A couple characters sound like they are talking through tin cans. Some moments that require "Oh, God, no!" sound more like "oh, gawd, noes..." These potentially exciting crescendos could have been intense and gripping, but they lose their weight when offered up in unenthusiastic, uneven presentation.

Perhaps I've been spoiled by the far above-average voice direction in Wadjet Eye games, but I believe those gems are the industry standard. 

A great deal of the horror lies in tropetastic reveals-- for instance, sometimes the lights go out, something spooky is shown, and  the lights come back on. Some of the scary is more than mild, but it's lost in a slew of teen-horror shlock padded by the ramblings of an incoherent raconteur. 

Charnel House would be so much more compelling if it were simply more interactive.You will be shuttled from one room to the next, sometimes solving extremely easy puzzles, sometimes just using the right item on the right environmental object. You will find yourself with no options to explore, and you are shackled with unsubtle directions to a paint-by-numbers game. 

Example:
Walk into train cabin.
Creepy but not exactly scary thing is going on.
Collect an item.
Leave cabin.
Use collected item to solve a "puzzle."
Hear a noise in the next train car.
"Oh, maybe I should go there," narrates the viewpoint character.
Go there.
Lights go out.
Creepy thing happens.
Repeat.

I'm not sure why the game is divided into chapters, since it is neither long enough nor diverse enough to require compartments (pun). I understand that the viewpoint character changes, but there are better, stronger methods of offering cliffhangers than sending the player back to the main menu every 30 minutes.

In the first and third chapters, you play the same character, a snarky lady with a penchant for cigarettes and bad relationships. In the second chapter you play an archaeology professor with a drinking problem who constanly loses his train of thought (pun). Each chapter will last you about 30-45 minutes, and since I only paid $2 for ~2 hours of mildly interesting, slightly spooky game, I'm not unhappy. But, I'm not really satisfied.

I wanted to jump on the train and love this game, but I think I'd rather throw myself on the tracks.

P.S. "Sepulchre" is definitely pronounced [sep.əl.kər], not [se.po͝ol.kər], New York Times Bestselling Author Madeline Roux.

(Edited to add more train-related puns)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993266228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1486842207}
review:
Score: 6.5 / 10
Price/Value: $5 CND or less 
Time: One and a half hours.

This is a rather short point-n-click title. The visuals are excellent for what it is; however, the voice acting is mediocre at best. Some of the characters sound like they are attempting accents rather poorly while others take a while to get up to speed. Many of you might recognize the voice of Jim Sterling from the popular 'Jimquisition' and he gives a delightful performance in the last chapter of the game. The role was one he seemed to have a lot of fun with and it comes out in his performance. 

As for if this is mystery or horror, I lean more towards mystery. The story is short and gives few details; yet there is something good here conceptually they have constructed which could flourish if nurtered properly. 

With the Steam Summer Sale around the corner do yourself a favour and pick it up on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061874207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1479991860}
review:
The Charnel House - идейный наследник Silent hill, только перенесенный в закрытое пространство поезда и выполненный в пиксельной графике The Lost Door. И эта простота идет игре на пользу - ярче бросаются в глаза создающие атмосферу сюжет и музыка. 
Происходящие события не назвать иначе, чем фантасмагорией, эдаким легким безумием, поражденным тоской и отчаянием главных героев. Игра пронизана упадническим духом, который, соединяясь с мистическими и реальными кошмарами, превращается в просто восхитительную, интригующую жуть, от которой невозможно оторваться.
В игре отсутствуют головоломки. Необходимые действия просты и понятны в 99% случаев, поэтому сюжет не буксует и подается равномерно, захватывая с головой.
Искренне рекомендую попробовать. И найти где-нибудь саундтрек, он того стоит.
